title: What do staff say about support from their managers and how has it changed?
analysis_commentary:
This question in the staff survey asks people to rank how supportive their managers are on a scale of 1 to 5 where a score of 1 represents unsupportive managers and 5 represents supportive managers. The average score has remained around 3.5 and varied very little since 2007. There has also been very little difference between different trust types although staff in ambulance trusts do report marginally lower values.

Further analysis reveals little difference between staff groups (medical/dental staff; registered nurses; healthcare assistants; health visitors; social care staff; allied health professionals, scientific & technical staff; general managers; wider healthcare team or staff characteristics (age, sex, disability and ethnicity - white vs. non-white).

The 2013 national report states in 2013, 69% of staff reported that their manager helps them with difficult tasks, 72% felt supported in a personal crisis, 57% feel that their manager gives them clear feedback about their work and 65% said they are satisfied with the support they get from their immediate manager.
data_source: Department of Health, Survey of NHS Staff
